trans-unit.source:
\n

Specifies the debugging mode for the just-in-time (JIT) compiler.

\n
trans-unit.target: $x$x$Xxxxxxxxx xxx xxxxxxxxx xxxx xxx xxx xxxx$xx$xxxx $XXX$ xxxxxxxx.$$x$$x

trans-unit.source:
\n

Instructs the just-in-time (JIT) compiler to use its default behavior, which includes enabling optimizations, disabling Edit and Continue support, and using symbol store sequence points if present.
trans-unit.target: $x$x$Xxxxxxxxx xxx xxxx$xx$xxxx $XXX$ xxxxxxxx xx xxx xxx xxxxxxx xxxxxxxx$ xxxxx xxxxxxxx xxxxxxxx xxxxxxxxxxxxx$ xxxxxxxxx Xxxx xxx Xxxxxxxx xxxxxxx$ xxx xxxxx xxxxxx xxxxx xxxxxxxx xxxxxx xx xxxxxxx.

trans-unit.source:
Starting with the .NET Framework version 2.0, JIT tracking information, the Microsoft intermediate language (MSIL) offset to the native-code offset within a method, is always generated.

\n
trans-unit.target: Xxxxxxxx xxxx xxx .XXX Xxxxxxxxx xxxxxxx 0.0$ XXX xxxxxxxx xxxxxxxxxxx$ xxx Xxxxxxxxx xxxxxxxxxxxx xxxxxxxx $XXXX$ xxxxxx xx xxx xxxxxx$xxxx xxxxxx xxxxxx x xxxxxx$ xx xxxxxx xxxxxxxxx.$$x$$x

trans-unit.source:
\n

Disable optimizations performed by the compiler to make your output file smaller, faster, and more efficient.
trans-unit.target: $x$x$Xxxxxxx xxxxxxxxxxxxx xxxxxxxxx xx xxx xxxxxxxx xx xxxx xxxx xxxxxx xxxx xxxxxxx$ xxxxxx$ xxx xxxx xxxxxxxxx.

trans-unit.source: Optimizations result in code rearrangement in the output file, which can make debugging difficult.
trans-unit.target: Xxxxxxxxxxxxx xxxxxx xx xxxx xxxxxxxxxxxxx xx xxx xxxxxx xxxx$ xxxxx xxx xxxx xxxxxxxxx xxxxxxxxx.

trans-unit.source: Typically optimization should be disabled while debugging.
trans-unit.target: Xxxxxxxxx xxxxxxxxxxxx xxxxxx xx xxxxxxxx xxxxx xxxxxxxxx.

trans-unit.source:
In versions 2.0 or later, combine this value with Default (Default | DisableOptimizations) to enable JIT tracking and disable optimizations.

\n
trans-unit.target: Xx xxxxxxxx 0.0 xx xxxxx$ xxxxxxx xxxx xxxxx xxxx Xxxxxxx $Xxxxxxx $ XxxxxxxXxxxxxxxxxxxx$ xx xxxxxx XXX xxxxxxxx xxx xxxxxxx xxxxxxxxxxxxx.$$x$$x

trans-unit.source: Edit and continue enables you to make changes to your source code while your program is in break mode.
trans-unit.target: Xxxx xxx xxxxxxxx xxxxxxx xxx xx xxxx xxxxxxx xx xxxx xxxxxx xxxx xxxxx xxxx xxxxxxx xx xx xxxxx xxxx.

trans-unit.source: The ability to edit and continue is compiler dependent.
trans-unit.target: Xxx xxxxxxx xx xxxx xxx xxxxxxxx xx xxxxxxxx xxxxxxxxx.

trans-unit.source:
\n

Use the implicit MSIL sequence points, not the program database (PDB) sequence points.
trans-unit.target: $x$x$Xxx xxx xxxxxxxx XXXX xxxxxxxx xxxxxx$ xxx xxx xxxxxxx xxxxxxxx $XXX$ xxxxxxxx xxxxxx.

trans-unit.source: The symbolic information normally includes at least one Microsoft intermediate language (MSIL) offset for each source line.
trans-unit.target: Xxx xxxxxxxx xxxxxxxxxxx xxxxxxxx xxxxxxxx xx xxxxx xxx Xxxxxxxxx xxxxxxxxxxxx xxxxxxxx $XXXX$ xxxxxx xxx xxxx xxxxxx xxxx.

trans-unit.source: When the just-in-time (JIT) compiler is about to compile a method, it asks the profiling services for a list of MSIL offsets that should be preserved.
trans-unit.target: Xxxx xxx xxxx$xx$xxxx $XXX$ xxxxxxxx xx xxxxx xx xxxxxxx x xxxxxx$ xx xxxx xxx xxxxxxxxx xxxxxxxx xxx x xxxx xx XXXX xxxxxxx xxxx xxxxxx xx xxxxxxxxx.

trans-unit.source:
These MSIL offsets are called sequence points.

\n
trans-unit.target: Xxxxx XXXX xxxxxxx xxx xxxxxx xxxxxxxx xxxxxx.$$x$$x
